items.title: Tesla shareholders approve $1tn pay package for Elon Musk
items.standfirst: Chants of ‘Elon’ erupt after compensation plan approved despite opposition from several high-profile investorsTesla shareholders approved a $1tn compensation plan for CEO Elon Musk on Thursday, awarding the world’s richest person what would be the largest corporate payout in history if he meets the goals necessary to receive it.The pay package, which several high-profile investors opposed, demonstrates that shareholders still believe Musk can lead the automaker in an era dominated by robotics and artificial intelligence. Continue reading...
items.content: Chants of ‘Elon’ erupt after compensation plan approved despite opposition from several high-profile investorsTesla shareholders approved a $1tn compensation plan for CEO Elon Musk on Thursday, awarding the world’s richest person what would be the largest corporate payout in history if he meets the goals necessary to receive it.The pay package, which several high-profile investors opposed, demonstrates that shareholders still believe Musk can lead the automaker in an era dominated by robotics and artificial intelligence. Continue reading...

Tesla shareholders approved a new executive pay package Thursday afternoon that would give Musk nearly $1 trillion in stock over the next decade, a record-shattering deal for the world’s richest man. The total award…

items.title: Peloton recalls more than 800,000 US exercise bikes over faulty seat post
items.standfirst: Shares fall as users urged to stop using bikes immediately and warned assembly poses risk of falls and injuriesThe US Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Thursday that Peloton Interactive was recalling about 833,000 units of its Original Bike+ Model PL02 after reports that the seat post assembly could break during use, posing a risk of falls and injuries.The consumer safety regulator said the fitness products maker had received three reports of the seat post breaking and detaching during use, including two incidents that resulted in injuries from falls. Continue reading...
items.content: Shares fall as users urged to stop using bikes immediately and warned assembly poses risk of falls and injuriesThe US Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Thursday that Peloton Interactive was recalling about 833,000 units of its Original Bike+ Model PL02 after reports that the seat post assembly could break during use, posing a risk of falls and injuries.The consumer safety regulator said the fitness products maker had received three reports of the seat post breaking and detaching during use, including two incidents that resulted in injuries from falls. items.title: How Tesla shareholders could make Elon Musk the world’s first trillionaire
items.standfirst: Shareholder votes on a pay package worth $1tn to be tallied 6 November – but it contains milestones beyond growing the company’s market capIf Elon Musk can grow Tesla to over $8tn in value for stockholders over the next decade, he will be well on his way to becoming the world’s first trillionaire.That is if stockholders approve the company’s latest proposed compensation plan for the “Superstar CEO”, as a judge once called him, at this week’s annual shareholders meeting in Austin, Texas, set for Thursday afternoon. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Tesla shareholders approved a compensation plan for CEO Elon Musk on Thursday, awarding him a large payout.
The pay package could be the largest corporate payout in history if Musk meets the goals.
Several high-profile investors opposed the pay package, but shareholders still approved it.
The package is expected to go into full effect by 2035 if Tesla hits financial targets.
Shareholders approved the pay package with as much as 75 percent support on Thursday.

clusters.title: Air traffic controllers' union chief: "These are real people with real lives"
clusters.neutral_headline: US Flight Cancellations Accelerate Due to Government Shutdown

items.title: Air traffic controllers' union chief: "These are real people with real lives"
items.standfirst: Airlines are preparing for a reduction in air traffic as the government shutdown drags on. Nick Daniels, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, joins "The Takeout" with his perspective on the impact of the stalemate.
items.content: Airlines are preparing for a reduction in air traffic as the government shutdown drags on. Nick Daniels, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, joins "The Takeout" with his perspective on the impact of the stalemate.

items.title: Airlines scramble to comply with FAA order cutting thousands of flights
items.standfirst: The FAA ordered airlines to cut thousands of flights starting Friday as the agency deals with air traffic controller shortages during the government shutdown.
items.content: The FAA ordered airlines to cut thousands of flights starting Friday as the agency deals with air traffic controller shortages during the government shutdown.

items.title: Airlines to gradually implement flight cuts due to shutdown
items.standfirst: Travelers at 40 airports across the U.S. could face flight delays and cancellations starting Friday as the FAA reduces air traffic due to the government shutdown. CBS News senior transportation correspondent Kris Van Cleave has the details.
items.content: Travelers at 40 airports across the U.S. could face flight delays and cancellations starting Friday as the FAA reduces air traffic due to the government shutdown. CBS News senior transportation correspondent Kris Van Cleave has the details.

(AP Production: Marissa Duhaney) U.S.…

items.title: Airlines and travelers scramble to prepare for cuts in air traffic
items.standfirst: Airlines are gearing up for a 10% reduction in flights ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration. The agency says it's necessary to keep the nation's airspace safe during the government shutdown.
items.content: Airlines are gearing up for a 10% reduction in flights ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration. The agency says it's necessary to keep the nation's airspace safe during the government shutdown.

items.title: New York, LA, Chicago and Washington DC airports among 40 facing air traffic reductions
items.standfirst: US government shutdown blamed for cuts from Friday, two weeks before busy Thanksgiving holiday travel periodUS politics live – latest updatesList of US airports cutting flights on Friday due to federal government shutdownNew York, Los Angeles and Chicago airports are among 40 that will see reductions in flights from Friday as a result of the government shutdown, according to a list distributed to the airlines.The Associated Press published the list after airline regulators identified “high-volume markets” where the Federal Administration Agency says air traffic must be reduced by 4% by 6am ET on Friday, a move that would force airlines to cancel thousands of flights and create a cascade of scheduling issues and delays at some of the nation’s largest airports. Continue reading...
items.content: US government shutdown blamed for cuts from Friday, two weeks before busy Thanksgiving holiday travel periodUS politics live – latest updatesList of US airports cutting flights on Friday due to federal government shutdownNew York, Los Angeles and Chicago airports are among 40 that will see reductions in flights from Friday as a result of the government shutdown, according to a list distributed to the airlines.The Associated Press published the list after airline regulators identified “high-volume markets” where the Federal Administration Agency says air traffic must be reduced by 4% by 6am ET on Friday, a move that would force airlines to cancel thousands of flights and create a cascade of scheduling issues and delays at some of the nation’s largest airports. Continue reading...

items.title: Airlines Rush to Prepare for Federal Reductions in Flights
items.standfirst: The affected airports, serving major cities including Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York, are expected to see a 4 percent reduction in air traffic on Friday, rising to 10 percent by the end of the weekend.
items.content: The affected airports, serving major cities including Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York, are expected to see a 4 percent reduction in air traffic on Friday, rising to 10 percent by the end of the weekend.

items.title: Airlines cut back flights at 40 US airports amid the shutdown. Here's what to do if your flight is delayed or canceled

Grace Hie Yoon/Anadolu via Getty Images Federal officials said 10% of flights will be cut at 40 US airports amid the government shutdown. Airlines must refund canceled…

items.title: Airlines likely to adjust load to accomodate passengers as US orders flight reductions, expert says
items.standfirst: The Trump administration has ordered flight reductions at major airports due to a shortage of air traffic controllers during the longest U.S. government shutdown in history. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Michael McCormick, Associate Professor and Program Coordinator for B.S. in Air Traffic Management at Embry-Riddle University, says that airlines are likely to start adjusting their load to cope with the reduction in the number of flights.
items.content: The Trump administration has ordered flight reductions at major airports due to a shortage of air traffic controllers during the longest U.S. government shutdown in history. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Michael McCormick, Associate Professor and Program Coordinator for B.S. in Air Traffic Management at Embry-Riddle University, says that airlines are likely to start adjusting their load to cope with the reduction in the number of flights.

items.title: Busiest US airports face flight reductions because of government shutdown
items.standfirst: Flight capacity will be cut at major airports as air traffic controllers report issues with fatigue amid staff shortages.
items.content: Flight capacity will be cut at major airports as air traffic controllers report issues with fatigue amid staff shortages.

items.title: These 40 airports could be impacted by the FAA's capacity cuts and flight cancellations
items.standfirst: The FAA's plan to slash airline capacity due to the government shutdown could hit some of the nation's busiest airports, including in Atlanta, Dallas, New York City and Los Angeles, according to a proposed list obtained by CBS News.
items.content: The FAA's plan to slash airline capacity due to the government shutdown could hit some of the nation's busiest airports, including in Atlanta, Dallas, New York City and Los Angeles, according to a proposed list obtained by CBS News.

items.title: Transportation secretary announces 10% reduction in U.S. air traffic
items.standfirst: The FAA will reduce U.S. air traffic by 10% at 40 U.S. locations starting on Friday due to the government shutdown.
items.content: The FAA will reduce U.S. air traffic by 10% at 40 U.S. locations starting on Friday due to the government shutdown.

items.title: FAA Plan to Cut Flights Might Not Be a Total Nightmare
items.standfirst: The US government is aiming to ease the pressure on air traffic controllers suffering shutdown-related woes by curtailing flights. But airlines have experience with this kind of sudden disruption.
items.content: The US government is aiming to ease the pressure on air traffic controllers suffering shutdown-related woes by curtailing flights. But airlines have experience with this kind of sudden disruption.

ai_summary: The FAA ordered airlines to cut thousands of flights due to air traffic controller shortages.
Airlines are preparing for a 10% reduction in flights ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration.
Airports in New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago will see flight cuts starting Friday.
The government shutdown is the reason for the flight reductions starting Friday.
Travelers at 40 airports could face delays and cancellations due to the shutdown.

clusters.title: Satellite image of livestock in Sudan misinterpreted as mass graves
clusters.neutral_headline: Sudan RSF Agrees to Ceasefire Proposal

items.title: Satellite image of livestock in Sudan misinterpreted as mass graves
items.standfirst: Following reported mass killings late October by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces in the beseiged city of El Fasher, internet users shared a screenshot from Google Earth purporting to show the site of a massacre. But according to satellite image analysts, this images are dated and in fact depict livestock. We spoke directly to the expert involved in this fact-check in this episode of Truth or Fake.
items.content: Following reported mass killings late October by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces in the beseiged city of El Fasher, internet users shared a screenshot from Google Earth purporting to show the site of a massacre. But according to satellite image analysts, this images are dated and in fact depict livestock. We spoke directly to the expert involved in this fact-check in this episode of Truth or Fake.

items.title: Sudan: RSF agree to truce proposal as new satellite images suggest 'mass graves' in El-Fasher
items.standfirst: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, who have been at war with the regular army for more than two years, have announced that they have agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by mediators. Meanwhile, Yale researchers released a report on Thursday stating that new satellite imagery had detected activity "consistent with mass graves" in the Sudanese city of El-Fasher, more than a week after mass killings were reported in the area.
items.content: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, who have been at war with the regular army for more than two years, have announced that they have agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by mediators. Meanwhile, Yale researchers released a report on Thursday stating that new satellite imagery had detected activity "consistent with mass graves" in the Sudanese city of El-Fasher, more than a week after mass killings were reported in the area.

items.title: RSF says it agrees to mediators’ ceasefire proposal in Sudan war
items.standfirst: Paramilitary says it will accept a ceasefire proposed by the Quad mediators - the US, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the UAE.
items.content: Paramilitary says it will accept a ceasefire proposed by the Quad mediators - the US, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the UAE.

items.title: Sudanese militia group accused of war crimes agrees to a ceasefire
items.standfirst: International mediators broker three-month halt to civil war as further evidence emerges of mass civilian killingsA Sudanese paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of unarmed civilians in an ethnically motivated massacre has agreed to a truce.The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which is facing mounting criticism over apparent war crimes committed by its fighters in the city of El Fasher last month, said it had agreed to a “humanitarian ceasefire” put forward by the quad countries of the US, Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia. Continue reading...
items.content: International mediators broker three-month halt to civil war as further evidence emerges of mass civilian killingsA Sudanese paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of unarmed civilians in an ethnically motivated massacre has agreed to a truce.The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which is facing mounting criticism over apparent war crimes committed by its fighters in the city of El Fasher last month, said it had agreed to a “humanitarian ceasefire” put forward by the quad countries of the US, Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia. Continue reading...

items.title: Sudan's RSF paramilitaries agree humanitarian ceasefire
items.standfirst: The group issued the statement after an 18-month siege of the city of el-Fasher in the western Darfur region.
items.content: The group issued the statement after an 18-month siege of the city of el-Fasher in the western Darfur region.

items.title: El-Fasher: 'The final battle of the Darfur Genocide that began in 2003'
items.standfirst: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, at war with the regular army for more than two years, announced on Thursday that they had agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by mediators. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Erin Ogunkeye welcomes Nathaniel Raymond, Executive Director at the YSPH Humanitarian Research Lab and Lecturer at Yale School of Public Health.
items.content: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, at war with the regular army for more than two years, announced on Thursday that they had agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by mediators. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Erin Ogunkeye welcomes Nathaniel Raymond, Executive Director at the YSPH Humanitarian Research Lab and Lecturer at Yale School of Public Health.

items.title: Sudan's RSF paramilitary group agrees to US-backed proposal for humanitarian truce
items.standfirst: Sudan's Rapid Support Force, a paramilitary group that has been at war with the Sudanese military for over two years, said Thursday it had agreed to a humanitarian truce that was proposed by a US-led mediator group known as the Quad. Sudan's army-aligned government indicated earlier this week that it would press on with the war.
items.content: Sudan's Rapid Support Force, a paramilitary group that has been at war with the Sudanese military for over two years, said Thursday it had agreed to a humanitarian truce that was proposed by a US-led mediator group known as the Quad. Sudan's army-aligned government indicated earlier this week that it would press on with the war.

items.title: Sudan's paramilitary forces agree to US-led proposal for humanitarian ceasefire
items.standfirst: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) say they have agreed to a US-led proposal for a humanitarian ceasefire.
items.content: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) say they have agreed to a US-led proposal for a humanitarian ceasefire.

items.title: Sudan paramilitary group agrees to a ceasefire proposal after massacre in an army stronghold it overran
items.standfirst: A paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of Sudanese civilians in a war that has triggered a catastrophic humanitarian crisis said Thursday it had agreed to a ceasefire proposal from U.S.-led mediators, although an American official indicated a final deal had not been struck yet
items.content: A paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of Sudanese civilians in a war that has triggered a catastrophic humanitarian crisis said Thursday it had agreed to a ceasefire proposal from U.S.-led mediators, although an American official indicated a final deal had not been struck yet

ai_summary: The RSF agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by mediators.
The RSF is facing criticism over apparent war crimes committed in El Fasher.
Yale researchers released a report stating new satellite imagery detected activity consistent with mass graves.
The RSF agreed to a ceasefire proposed by the Quad mediators: US, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and the UAE.
The RSF has been at war with the regular army for more than two years.

clusters.title: San Francisco leaders thank Nancy Pelosi for decades of service
clusters.neutral_headline: Nancy Pelosi Won't Seek Reelection, Ending Career

items.title: San Francisco leaders thank Nancy Pelosi for decades of service
items.standfirst: Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on Thursday that she will not seek reelection and will step down at the end of her term in 2027. CBS News Bay Area reporter Lauren Toms has more on how San Francisco political leaders are reacting.
items.content: Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on Thursday that she will not seek reelection and will step down at the end of her term in 2027. CBS News Bay Area reporter Lauren Toms has more on how San Francisco political leaders are reacting.

items.title: Nancy Pelosi won't seek reelection, ending her storied career in the US House
Nancy Pelosi won't seek reelection, ending her storied career in the US House
items.standfirst: Nancy Pelosi, the first woman to serve as the powerful speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, said on Thursday that she will not run for re-election to Congress in 2026, ending a four-decade career of a progressive Democratic icon often vilified by the right. FRANCE 24's Monte Francis reports.
items.content: Nancy Pelosi, the first woman to serve as the powerful speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, said on Thursday that she will not run for re-election to Congress in 2026, ending a four-decade career of a progressive Democratic icon often vilified by the right. FRANCE 24's Monte Francis reports.

items.title: Nancy Pelosi announces retirement after decades in US Congress
items.standfirst: Pelosi made history as the first female Speaker and left an indelible mark on US politics.
items.content: Pelosi made history as the first female Speaker and left an indelible mark on US politics.

items.title: Nancy Pelosi, former House speaker, to retire from Congress after this term
items.standfirst: Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced Thursday she will not seek reelection and will retire from Congress at the end of her term.
items.content: Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced Thursday she will not seek reelection and will retire from Congress at the end of her term.

items.title: Nancy Pelosi, first female US House speaker, to retire from Congress
items.standfirst: Powerful Democrat Pelosi, 85, says she will not seek re-election, but she will finish the final year of her term.
items.content: Powerful Democrat Pelosi, 85, says she will not seek re-election, but she will finish the final year of her term.

items.title: Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi will not seek reelection
items.standfirst: A shrewd political strategist, California Rep. Nancy Pelosi has had an unprecedented career in Congress. First elected in 1987, Pelosi became one of the most effective leaders of the Democratic Party.
items.content: A shrewd political strategist, California Rep. Nancy Pelosi has had an unprecedented career in Congress. First elected in 1987, Pelosi became one of the most effective leaders of the Democratic Party.(Image credit: Leigh Vogel)

ai_summary: Nancy Pelosi announced she will not seek reelection and will retire at the end of her term.
Pelosi served as the first female Speaker of the House.
Pelosi's career spanned four decades in the US Congress.
She will finish the final year of her term.
San Francisco leaders are reacting to Pelosi's retirement announcement.

clusters.title: Judge orders Trump administration to fully fund SNAP benefits for November
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge Orders Trump Administration to Fully Fund SNAP Benefits

items.title: Judge orders Trump administration to fully fund SNAP benefits for November
items.standfirst: U.S. District Judge John McConnell ordered the Trump administration to provide the full food stamp benefits by Friday.

items.title: US judge orders Trump administration to fully fund Snap benefits in November
items.standfirst: Ruling comes in response to a challenge to administration’s offer to only partly fund US food benefits amid shutdownA federal judge in Rhode Island ordered the Trump administration on Thursday to find the money to fully fund food stamps for 42 million low-income Americans in November by Friday, in a rebuke to the government’s plan to only provide reduced aid during the shutdown.US district judge John J McConnell Jr criticized the administration’s plan to partly fund Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits in November, saying it had failed to comply with an order he issued on Saturday requiring the government to ensure Americans received full or partial benefits no later than Wednesday. Continue reading...

He’s hammered home his wishes on Truth Social, and in front of lawmakers at a White House breakfast on Tuesday. Continue reading...

clusters.title: US supreme court lets Trump block passport sex markers for trans and non-binary people
clusters.neutral_headline: Supreme Court Lets Trump Block Passport Sex Markers

items.title: US supreme court lets Trump block passport sex markers for trans and non-binary people
items.standfirst: Decision by high court’s conservative majority is Trump administration’s latest win on emergency docketThe supreme court on Thursday allowed Donald Trump’s administration to enforce a policy blocking transgender and non-binary people from choosing passport sex markers that align with their gender identity.The decision by the high court’s conservative majority is Trump’s latest win on the high court’s emergency docket, and it means his administration can enforce the policy while a lawsuit over it plays out. It halts a lower-court order requiring the government to keep letting people choose male, female or X on their passport to line up with their gender identity on new or renewed passports. Continue reading...
items.content: Decision by high court’s conservative majority is Trump administration’s latest win on emergency docketThe supreme court on Thursday allowed Donald Trump’s administration to enforce a policy blocking transgender and non-binary people from choosing passport sex markers that align with their gender identity.The decision by the high court’s conservative majority is Trump’s latest win on the high court’s emergency docket, and it means his administration can enforce the policy while a lawsuit over it plays out. It halts a lower-court order requiring the government to keep letting people choose male, female or X on their passport to line up with their gender identity on new or renewed passports. Continue reading...

items.title: Philippines declares state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi death toll passes 100
items.standfirst: The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, with 127 people still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of CebuPhilippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr has declared a state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and nearly 130 missing in central provinces in the deadliest natural disaster to hit the country this year.The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, and 127 people were still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of Cebu. The tropical cyclone blew out of the archipelago on Wednesday into the South China Sea. Continue reading...

items.title: Rockstar Games delays Grand Theft Auto VI – again – to late 2026
items.standfirst: The hugely anticipated sequel was due to arrive in May of next year but has been pushed back to November 2026Rockstar Games’s Grand Theft Auto VI, which was due to release on 26 May next year, has been delayed again – this time to the end of 2026. It has now been nearly two years since the game was announced, and more than 12 years since the release of Grand Theft Auto V.“Grand Theft Auto VI will now release on Thursday, November 19, 2026,” reads Rockstar Games’s statement on X. “We are sorry for adding additional time to what we realize has been a long wait, but these extra months will allow us to finish the game with the level of polish you have come to expect and deserve.” Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: Ugandans view Mamdani’s NYC win as a ‘beacon of hope’ amid democratic struggle

items.title: Pride in Uganda after Mamdani’s victory in the New York mayoral race
items.standfirst: Ugandans in Kampala react to the election of Zohran Mamdani as New York’s new mayor. Born in Uganda and now the city’s first Muslim mayor, Mamdani’s victory sparks pride and hope – with many young people inspired by his progressive agenda and stance against Trump-era policies.
items.content: Ugandans in Kampala react to the election of Zohran Mamdani as New York’s new mayor. Born in Uganda and now the city’s first Muslim mayor, Mamdani’s victory sparks pride and hope – with many young people inspired by his progressive agenda and stance against Trump-era policies.

items.title: Ugandans view Mamdani’s NYC win as a ‘beacon of hope’ amid democratic struggle
items.standfirst: Ugandans react with joy after Kampala-born Mamdani’s victory during a trying time for democracy in east AfricaUgandans reacted with joy and hope to the news that Kampala-born Zohran Mamdani had been elected mayor of New York City, amid a stormy democratic and rights environment in east Africa.Mamdani, who was born in Uganda 34 years ago to a family of Indian origin, on Tuesday defeated former governor Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa to become the city’s first Muslim mayor and the first of south Asian heritage. Continue reading...
items.content: Ugandans react with joy after Kampala-born Mamdani’s victory during a trying time for democracy in east AfricaUgandans reacted with joy and hope to the news that Kampala-born Zohran Mamdani had been elected mayor of New York City, amid a stormy democratic and rights environment in east Africa.Mamdani, who was born in Uganda 34 years ago to a family of Indian origin, on Tuesday defeated former governor Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa to become the city’s first Muslim mayor and the first of south Asian heritage. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Ugandans reacted with joy to Zohran Mamdani's New York City mayoral victory.
Mamdani was born in Uganda and is the city's first Muslim mayor.
His victory is seen as a beacon of hope amid democratic struggles.
Mamdani defeated former governor Andrew Cuomo and Curtis Sliwa.
He is the first mayor of South Asian heritage in New York City.

items.content: In addition to affordability, New York City’s mayor-elect will be forced to reckon with the NYPD’s sweeping mass surveillance operations.

items.title: World’s oldest president sworn in for eighth term in Cameroon
items.standfirst: Paul Biya has been in power since 1982 - the opposition says the election was rigged.
items.content: Paul Biya has been in power since 1982 - the opposition says the election was rigged.

items.title: Cameroon: World’s oldest president sworn in for eighth term
items.standfirst: Cameroon’s Paul Biya has been sworn in for his eighth consecutive term after winning last month’s presidential election. Issa Tchiroma Bakary, the other presidential candidate, maintains that he was the rightful winner of the poll and has accused the authorities of fraud - allegations they have denied.
items.content: Cameroon’s Paul Biya has been sworn in for his eighth consecutive term after winning last month’s presidential election. Issa Tchiroma Bakary, the other presidential candidate, maintains that he was the rightful winner of the poll and has accused the authorities of fraud - allegations they have denied.

ai_summary: Paul Biya was sworn in for his eighth term as president of Cameroon.
Biya has been in power since 1982.
The opposition claims the election was rigged.
Issa Tchiroma Bakary alleges he was the rightful winner.
Bakary has accused authorities of election fraud.

clusters.title: Louvre security failures exposed in report by France's auditing body
clusters.neutral_headline: Louvre heist a ‘deafening wake-up call’, says auditor

items.title: Louvre security failures exposed in report by France's auditing body
items.standfirst: France's court of auditors urged the Louvre museum to speed up its security modernisation plans as a priority, in a report conducted before the jewel heist that noted major delays in the renovation of the world’s most-visited museum. It said the museum's investments prioritised “visible and attractive operations” like buying new pieces of art and improving visitor experience at the expense of the maintenance and renovation of buildings and technical installations.
items.content: France's court of auditors urged the Louvre museum to speed up its security modernisation plans as a priority, in a report conducted before the jewel heist that noted major delays in the renovation of the world’s most-visited museum. It said the museum's investments prioritised “visible and attractive operations” like buying new pieces of art and improving visitor experience at the expense of the maintenance and renovation of buildings and technical installations.

items.title: Louvre heist a ‘deafening wake-up call’, says auditor
items.standfirst: Report says Paris museum prioritised ‘visible and attractive’ projects over security in run-up to robberyEurope live – latest updatesThe spectacular theft of an estimated €88m (£77m) of crown jewels from the Louvre last month was “a deafening wake-up call” for the “wholly inadequate pace” of security upgrades at the Paris museum, the head of France’s state auditor has said.Presenting the report, which was completed before the dramatic heist at the world’s most-visited museum, Pierre Moscovici said the Louvre had sufficient funds for the improvements and “must now implement them without fail”. Continue reading...
items.content: Report says Paris museum prioritised ‘visible and attractive’ projects over security in run-up to robberyEurope live – latest updatesThe spectacular theft of an estimated €88m (£77m) of crown jewels from the Louvre last month was “a deafening wake-up call” for the “wholly inadequate pace” of security upgrades at the Paris museum, the head of France’s state auditor has said.Presenting the report, which was completed before the dramatic heist at the world’s most-visited museum, Pierre Moscovici said the Louvre had sufficient funds for the improvements and “must now implement them without fail”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A report criticized the Louvre's security measures.
The report was completed before the recent jewel heist.
The auditor said the museum prioritized "visible" projects over security.
The Louvre had sufficient funds for security improvements.
The museum is urged to implement security upgrades without delay.

clusters.title: 2 elderly lions euthanized, fate of 5 more uncertain after wildlife sanctuary hit by financial woes
clusters.neutral_headline: Troubled New Zealand wildlife park euthanizes two lions, fate of five more unclear

items.title: 2 elderly lions euthanized, fate of 5 more uncertain after wildlife sanctuary hit by financial woes
items.standfirst: A New Zealand wildlife sanctuary says it has euthanized two of its seven elderly lions after closing for financial reasons, with five more at risk of the same fate.
items.content: A New Zealand wildlife sanctuary says it has euthanized two of its seven elderly lions after closing for financial reasons, with five more at risk of the same fate.

items.title: Troubled New Zealand wildlife park euthanizes two lions, fate of five more unclear
items.standfirst: Members of the public have pleaded for a reprieve for the remaining lions, while former staff members hope the sanctuary will reconsider putting them downA troubled New Zealand wildlife park says it has been forced to euthanise two of its elderly lions, with the fate of its remaining five lions unclear, after it ran into financial difficulties.The privately owned Kamo Wildlife Sanctuary in the northern city of Whangārei closed its doors on the weekend. Continue reading...
items.content: Members of the public have pleaded for a reprieve for the remaining lions, while former staff members hope the sanctuary will reconsider putting them downA troubled New Zealand wildlife park says it has been forced to euthanise two of its elderly lions, with the fate of its remaining five lions unclear, after it ran into financial difficulties.The privately owned Kamo Wildlife Sanctuary in the northern city of Whangārei closed its doors on the weekend. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A New Zealand wildlife sanctuary euthanized two elderly lions.
The sanctuary closed due to financial difficulties.
The fate of the remaining five lions is uncertain.
The public has pleaded for the remaining lions to be spared.
Former staff hope the sanctuary will reconsider the decision.
